key_points: U.S. Sen. Bill Cassidy feels 'at peace' with his vote to convict former President Donald Trump at his impeachment trial.
Cassidy faced criticism and censure from the Louisiana Republican Party but believes this does not represent the broader party opinion.
He was one of seven Senate Republicans who voted to convict Trump for inciting the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol.
Cassidy's vote diverged from Louisiana's other U.S. senator, John Kennedy, who voted against conviction.
Despite backlash, Cassidy has received support and respect from some Republicans for his decision.
The senator stands by his oath to support and defend the Constitution.
The 57-43 Senate vote fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to convict Trump.
Some Republicans who acquitted Trump disputed the evidence or rejected Congress's jurisdiction over a former president.
Post-impeachment, Cassidy has sought to focus on other issues, including Bidenâ€™s cabinet confirmations and weather recovery efforts.
Trump supporters continue to criticize Cassidy, leading to calls for his exclusion from Republican events and more local GOP groups condemning his vote.
